none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. D. Read, March 15, 1893
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. D. Read, March 15, 1893
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 10 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]
Sherman Tex
Mar 15" 1893

Prof. L. L. McInnis:
              Dear friend:
I received your letter en=
closing report of Committee. I had
seen it in Sundays "Houston
Post" & read it with a great
deal of interest. I had heard
that there was some complaint
against the Surgeon for allowing
boys to go home with fever on
them & for not excusing boys
except when they had fever &c,
but I had no idea that it
amounted to enough to be men=
tioned by the Commitee. I think
the report would have been stronger
even than it was, but for fear
that it would be regarded

**My Final Thoughts on Transcribing this Letter** Right, here we go. The task is to transcribe a handwritten letter, and I'm treating this like I'm meticulously examining the actual document. First, I need to understand the basic structure: It's a letter, ink on paper, with a clear date and location in the top right corner: "Sherman Tex" "Mar 15" 1893". I note the recipient is "Prof. L. L. McInnis:" and the salutation is "Dear friend:". Now for the body of the letter. I need to get every word, and the layout, exactly right. I see there are line breaks, and those must be preserved. I also have to pay close attention to any peculiarities. "Sherman Tex". The 'T' in "Tex" is cursive, standard. The date "Mar 15" 1893". The "15" followed by an obscure symbol. It looks like double quotes or possibly a ditto mark to show an ordinal. Let's transcribe that: "15"". "Prof. L. L. McInnis:". The name looks like "McInnis". It has dots near the 'c' but there is a 'c'. It is stylized. The 'I' is clear, and the overall name looks like "McInnis". Let's stick with that. The salutation is standard. The body itself has some line breaks and I will transcribe those. "en=closing" - this is where the word is broken. I'll need to preserve that. The word continues on the next line. "Sundays" - no apostrophe. "Houston Post" - I see quotes around "Houston", and another quote after "Post", so let's transcribe that as "Houston Post". The ampersand " & " is used. "Surgeon" is capitalized. "fever on them" - clear. " &c," is used. "men=tioned" - another word break with an equals sign. The word "Commitee" is spelled strangely. The word "stronger" is clear. "regarded" appears cut off at the bottom. Now, I'm thinking about formatting. The date and location will be right-aligned, because that's where they appear on the page. I'll need to use standard HTML tags: `

Dear friend:". And then the body of the letter: I'll carefully transcribe each line, preserving the line breaks, including "en=" and "men=". Now, a very careful check. The double quotes for the date ("15"") are definitely there. "McInnis" is "McInnis". The "dots" are stylization, it is "Mc". I'll keep "McInnis". "Sundays" has no apostrophe, confirmed. The ampersand is used. It is "Commitee" and "Commitee" in line 13. The word break is a double dash ("="). "Surgeon" is capitalized. "fever" lowercase. "&c" - confirmed. The word "regarded" - clear. Re-checking "Commitee": line 3 and line 13. I'll stick to what the letters look like. And again, "Sundays" - no apostrophe. "Post" has quotes: `Post"`. `Mar 15"` - confirmed. I will use `

as a partisan paper & thus fail
of accomplishing its purpose
"The Dallas News" has al =
ready treated it as a stab
at Ross & purely an administra -
tion report. & those whom I
have heard speak of it seem
to consider it purely political
Most people that have spoken
to me on the subject say that
there is no reason for the ex =
istence of the "A & M C" - it is
a useless expense upon the
State & a school for the devel =
opment of vice &c. Ex Senator
Weisiger of Victoria who has
a son here at College, has re =
cently been on an extended
visit to his son who had pneu
monia & I have had frequent
talks with him. He said that
it was generally understood

**Here's how I approached this transcription task:**

Right, let's break this down. First, I had to understand the rules of the game: a professional transcription, preserving the quirks of the original, all while wrangling some HTML tags. Got it. Now, the image itself - a handwritten letter, likely from the late 19th or early 20th century, with all the usual suspects: faded ink, lined paper, and cursive script. The content pointed towards discussions of "The Dallas News," A&M College, and some political commentary involving a former Senator Weisiger.

Okay, time to get my hands dirty. I started line by line, wrestling with the script, re-evaluating each word, each letter. The first line was a bit tricky. That "paper" threw me for a loop initially – that 'p' looked a little wonky. But context is king! "Partisan paper" made sense, especially considering the reference to "The Dallas News" later on. I checked the "p" in "people" (Line 9) to confirm my understanding. And don't forget that sneaky superscript 'a' – the formatting gods demand accuracy!

Moving on, the challenge was in deciphering the writer's penmanship. "Administration" was another word that required close study, specifically the "tion" that looked like "zion". I kept going back and forth, re-reading the surrounding words, and paying close attention to the way the letters were formed. "A & M C" needed a quick clarification too. The ampersand was clear, but the letters were written very casually.

The dashes at the end of lines were worth a second (and third!) look. Should I use an equals sign or a simple dash? It had to be consistent to be accurate. I decided that, since some were clearly two strokes (as in `=`), they should be represented with an equals sign. Line 5 was clearly a single dash though ("administra -").

Then, it was all about fine-tuning: ensuring the HTML tags were correctly placed and that any minor visual cues (like the lack of a hyphen after "pneu") were faithfully preserved. I had to double-check that the tags I was using (`p`, `sup`, `br`) were the only ones permitted.

The final review was a meticulous cross-comparison of my transcribed text against the image, line by line, to guarantee accuracy. No stone unturned. And finally, I had my output – a faithful representation of the original text, ready to be delivered.

as to send him to the "A + M C"

notwithstanding its mismanage
= ment. This with the amount
received from the U S. Govrmt
- about $50 000 + from students
nearly $50.000 - more, will
be nearly a quarter of a million
- the last two amounts are for
one year. Double them + the
amount spent in two years will

I opted for the symbol that was visually presented. I also had to contend with a crossed-out word, which was not allowed to be transcribed with a strike-through. Since my instructions were to transcribe the text that was meant to be read, I decided to omit the word to respect the original intent. The transcription also revealed a few cases of numbers with a space, so I kept them. I needed to ensure that the layout was preserved, which led me to include the appropriate HTML tags. I also determined that the instructions to maintain the original layout meant that I should maintain line breaks. The layout of the original text seemed to be two paragraphs, so I used the `

#320.000 - I dont think the
state receives enough benefit
in return for this expendi=
ture to warrant it. Give
Austin College half of this
sum + it will become the
leading institution of learn=
ing in the state in a few
years. In fact the grade
of scholarship required for
graduation is now higher
than any other college in
Texas. The Faculty, inclu=
ding President are now
paid with $6.600 - about
$400 more than it now
costs the state to run the
office of Presdt of the A + M C
+ If we count interest on money
invested in residence + furniture
for the Presdt - it will amount
to about $200. more than
the amount paid all the Profs

_ [1893, March 15]

of Austin college . I see
an edetorial in this morn =
ings "Dallas News" on "poli =

Now I would like to hear
your gun go off. I have
thought of preparing an ar =
ticle for the press on the sub =
ject of my removal; but would
prefer having it come from some
one else . If the Board claim
in their reply that I was re =
moved for incompetence , I will
institute suit for damages

**Transcription Process: A Detailed Walkthrough** Alright, let's break this down. My task is crystal clear: I'm a transcriptionist, and I need to render this handwritten text into a digital format, meticulously adhering to the provided instructions. I need to be exact. No commentary, just the words. Formatting is key, preserving line breaks and any quirks of the original. I'm provided specific HTML tags, which I'll use. First, I examine the image. It's a handwritten letter, that looks to be cursive. It's brown ink, on lined paper, typical of the era. The handwriting is generally legible, thankfully, and gives us some context around legal or political topics. I'm picking up words like "lawyer," "committee," "removal," "appointment," "Austin," and "legislature." This context informs how I approach the transcription. Now, I'm going line by line, trying to read each word exactly. I note my initial transcription, trying to match the script precisely, even the "be=" and "=ly" for hyphenated words. Then comes the fine-tuning. I look for spelling and punctuation errors. I note the hyphens, possessives and ampersands. I notice "Ross'" and the "&c" as shorthand for etcetera. I'm focusing on those potential apostrophes, hyphens and ampersands. I also see that the text wraps from one line to the next and note those hyphens. I am paying attention to the apostrophe in "Ross'". Now, the apostrophe and hyphen can be tricky in this cursive. In the last word, "don't" (I decide, I'll transcribe "don't" since it is standard), there's a cross on the t, which sometimes serves as an apostrophe. I'm looking for anything that might indicate it is a "t" as opposed to "t". I look closely and go back and forth. Based on the handwriting standard for this era and the handwriting, it could be written "dont", so I will be flexible in the rendering - and in the rendering of a similar word. I look for consistency and will make a judgment. In the end, it trails off, and I will be faithful to the visual. I will stick to the literal strokes unless I am confident. I then structure the text as an HTML block, wrapping the entire transcription in `

` tags to represent a paragraph, and using `
` tags to preserve line breaks as they are in the original. I am carefully transcribing to retain the visual aspect. I'm checking: is there only text, no interpretation? Yes. Have I only used the approved tags? Yes. Have I preserved the spelling and formatting? Yes. I double-check. The "be=" and "=ly" hyphens. The "&c" and ampersands. The faint apostrophes. The way the lines end and start. The gaps. I make adjustments. I am meticulously rendering. I'm looking closely. I read the final output to check it is perfect. The result, I believe, is an accurate and compliant transcription. ```html

want to assume the role
of an applicant for sympa=
thy on account of my mis=
fortune. I still retain the
spirit of a soldier and
only ask for a fair fight
& for truth. If I am men=
tioned in the reply of the
Board, I shall open fire
& make it warm for them.
I wrote to one of our repre=

**My Analysis of this Handwritten Document** Okay, so I'm presented with a handwritten document, looks like a letter, and my job is to get a transcription of it. Let's see... the handwriting is cursive, which is always fun. I'm going to take this line by line and try to get it right. First, the opening. The person seems to be adopting a role, applying for sympathy because of "misfortune" — that's the hyphenated word there, "mis=fortune". There's also the phrase "sympa=thy" indicating the hyphenation. They claim to still have the spirit of a soldier. The writer is asking for a "fair fight" and for "truth". I'm marking those emphasized words as requested. The writer mentions if they are brought up by the board they'll "open fire". They also wrote to "repre=sentatives" over a week ago, asking for a report from the committee. They "have'nt" heard back — there's an apostrophe there, or maybe not. I'll include it in the transcription as "have'nt". The person mentions someone in the legislature from "this Co" – probably county. They call him a "Clark man." Is it "Black man"? No, the C is very clear. It's a "Clark man," I'm certain. He's also described as "an ex Confederate an", then it continues as "honest, fearless man." It's likely the writer has repeated the use of 'an' intentionally. It continues that Dills is the man they're talking about. I'm noting this is a single paragraph as the text goes all the way through, from top to bottom. I'm making sure to capture those underlines on "fair fight" and "truth." Can't use HTML underlines, so I'm using `` tags as per the constraints of the allowable HTML. I've got the hyphenations: "sympa=", "mis=", "men=" and "repre=". The ampersands are also as they were written. Now, let's format this for the final output per specifications, maintaining all the breaks. Here is the final transcription.

writing to him + stating that
the report of the committa is
very mild. But enough!
for this time. I shall
watch the fight with in=
terest + may take a hand
myself before the war is
over. What was the mat
ter with Curtis? afraid

I opened this to read to Mrs R - It looks
like it had been tampered with

**Detailed Transcription and Analysis** Alright, let's get down to this. I've got this handwritten letter in front of me, and my initial thought is that this is going to be an interesting one. The script is clearly cursive, and it’s got that feel of late 19th or early 20th-century writing – a bit hurried, but generally legible. My primary goal here is to get a clean transcription, but I’m going to do it meticulously. First thing's first, I need to get the formatting right. `

` for paragraphs, `
` for line breaks. And I see a sort of marginal note, a filing mark maybe, and I'll need to figure out how to incorporate that. There's a pencil note as well, at the bottom. So, let's start reading: * I read the first line: "writing to him + stating that". The plus sign is clearly used for the ampersand. * Line 2: "the report of the committa is". "Committa"? Does this mean "committee"? The end of the word looks like an 'a' at first. However, the writer makes their 'e's like loops. I will write "committa" as seen, but I need to be ready to correct this if context demands it. No, it is "committa". This is the first ambiguity, but I must transcribe what I *see*. * Line 3: "very mild. But enough!" - the punctuation is clear. * Line 4: "for this time. I shall" * Line 5: "watch the fight with in=" - a hyphen, indicating a continued word "interest". * Line 6: "terest + may take a hand" - "terest" again, and another plus sign, for the ampersand. * Line 7: "myself before the war is" * Line 8: "over. What was the mat" * Line 9: "ter with Curtis? afraid" * Line 10: "of exposures? - Do you" * Line 11: "think Sbesa's salary will" - "Sbesa's" is where the work will start, because it's not immediately obvious and I should note any ambiguity. It looks like it is S-b-e-s-a-'s, or maybe S-h-e-s-a-'s. Let's trace letters: The 'b' or 'h' looks close to the other 'b's and 'h's. Is there a "Sbesa's" in the archives? I'll transcribe "Sbesa's" as the closest thing to what I'm seeing. This is another area of concern. Let's see if context helps. * Line 12: "be cut down - Write me" - a dash. * Line 13: "more at length - Give" - a dash. * Line 14: "our regards to Mrs A -" - the 'A' is clear, and a dash at the end. * Line 15: "when you write + tell" * Line 16: "her to write us + send" * Line 17: "us anything of interest" - a good stopping place. * Line 18: "on the fight - she is on". Wait. It looks like the writer made an insertion above "She is on..." Here, it seems the writer is writing "on the fight..." and they inserted this above "she is on...". So, the transcription is: "us anything of interest / on the fight - she is on the ground." It looks like it. Okay, the layout is clear, now. "on the fight" is between two lines. It seems "on the fight" is not a margin note but the writer ran out of space. * Line 19: "the ground. Mrs R + Thorn". There's a "+", and "Thorn" ends the line. * Line 20: "=ton send kind regards to". There is an equals sign as a hyphen. So it's "Thornton". * Line 21: "you all. Your friend". * Now, the signature is next. It looks like "J S Read". I'm going with an "S" initial. It’s got that classic cursive “S” shape. * Now, I have this pencil note at the bottom: "NB 1893" is on the bottom left margin. I'll need to figure out how to incorporate that.
